conclusion: To find the magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground, follow these steps:
The force exerted by the adult is \( F = 100 \, 	ext{N} \) at an angle of \( 37^\circ \) above the horizontal.

premise: The force exerted by the adult is \( F = 100 \, 	ext{N} \) at an angle of \( 37^\circ \) above the horizontal.
conclusion: The vertical component of the force (\( F_y \)) is \( F_y = F \sin 37^\circ = 100 	imes 0.6 = 60 \, 	ext{N} \).
The combined mass of the child and sled is \( m = 30 \, 	ext{kg} + 10 \, 	ext{kg} = 40 \, 	ext{kg} \).

premise: The combined mass of the child and sled is \( m = 30 \, 	ext{kg} + 10 \, 	ext{kg} = 40 \, 	ext{kg} \).
conclusion: The weight (\( W \)) is \( W = m \cdot g = 40 	imes 10 = 400 \, 	ext{N} \).
Since the sled is moving at a constant speed, the vertical forces are balanced.

premise: The weight (\( W \)) is \( 400 \, 	ext{N} \) and the vertical component of the force (\( F_y \)) is \( 60 \, 	ext{N} \).
conclusion: The normal force (\( N \)) is the weight minus the vertical component of the pulling force: \( N = W - F_y = 400 - 60 = 340 \, 	ext{N} \).

premise: The normal force (\( N \)) is \( 340 \, 	ext{N} \).
conclusion: The magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is equal to the normal force: \( 	ext{Magnitude of pressure} = 340 \, 	ext{N} \).
